title: What does the Bible say about judging? - Quora

response.answer_text: Despite the simplicity of this concept, I think the quotation “judge not lest you be judged” is frequently misunderstood by individuals who don't have a sound theological understanding. In many cases, these individuals might be non-Christians who like to frequently accuse Christians of hypocrisy. I think the word judge in this context means something closer to “determining a verdict on someone that might include a punishment” rather than “forming an opinion about the behaviors of others.” When a Christian tells someone else that a certain behavior is wrong, that's not equivalent to “judging” someone, according to scripture. In fact, Christians are morally obligated to speak out against immoral behavior. To take an extreme example, the two individuals who went on a shooting spree at Columbine High School, in Colorado, were atheists. They were motivated to commit this atrocity due to their hatred of Christians. During their killing spree, they specifically targeted Christians. They asked two girls if they believed in Jesus Christ. The one who said “yes” was shot in the head. The one who said “no” was allowed to go. Imagine if these two atheists had a dialogue with a Christian friend before the shooting: Atheist: “Hey, bro, Dylan and I are thinking about shooting up the school in about a week.” Christian: “I think that's wrong and that you shouldn't do it. The Bible says you shouldn't kill.” Atheist: “The Bible also says ‘judge not, lest ye be judged,’ you hypocrite. Are you judging us, bro?” Christian: “I believe the King James Version of the Bible states that. I prefer the Catholic Revised Standard Version of the Bible.” Atheist: “Stop being a smart ass. You were judging us and you're god says don't judge. Your a hypocrite.” Christian: “I just shared my opinion. I wasn't judging you. I think that shooting up the school would be wrong. How is sharing an opinion from a Christian perspective equivalent to hypocrisy?” Atheist: “Your lucky your our friend and play dungeons and dragons with us. Otherwise, I'd shoot you in the face right now.” Atheist 2: “Yeah, he’s, like, the only cool Christian we know.” Christian: “Whatever, I hope you guys are just joking. You're both sick in the head. Hey, it's my turn to be Dungeon Master next Friday night, a week from now, right?” Atheist: “Ah, actually, we rescheduled that Dungeons and Dragons session to five days from now. We're going to play hookie, skip school, and just play Dungeons and Dragons all day.” Atheist 2: “Yeah, we already forged a doctor’s note that looks like it was written by your mom. Here you go. Just stay home that day. We’ll meet you at your house.” Christian: “Awesome, guys. Thanks!” Informing someone on the moral code contained in the New Testament isn't the equivalent of judging them. I think that word “judgement” in the context of the New Testament Koine Greek logically involves an earthly punishment coupled with a specific “judgement.” For example, Jesus saved the adulterous woman from the “judgement” of death by stoning (the act of throwing rocks at her until she died). To simplify, my Christian interpretation of “do not judge” is to not throw rocks at people. Pointing out sinful behavior, from a Christian theological perspective, doesn't qualify as “judging” someone.
